IRS990.MissionDescription: The Mission of the Fulton County Medical Center is "To continuously improve the health of our community." We perform this mission by:* Providing diagnostic and therapeutic services in our acute care hospital; * Maintaining health and providing a higher quality of life in our community by operating a nursing home and a home care program; * Offering access to care through a multi-specialty clinic; and * Working with other local providers and agencies to promote wellness in our community.
IRS990.Description: Fulton County Medical Center provides inpatient, outpatient, emergency care, skilled nursing, and home health services. Services are provided to all who need them, regardless of ability to pay. Emergency services are provided 24/7, 365 days a year, without inquiry into financial means or insurance status. Elective services are provided with financial assistance offered based upon a standard, objective application to determine financial need. Services may be discounted from established rates or provided free of charge after the application and supporting documentation have been evaluated. Discounts and allowances offered under the medical centers financial assistance program totaled $259,608 based on charges foregone during the fiscal year ended June 30, 2010. The amount of the discount is determined by the type of service received such as inpatient, outpatient, etc. Interest-free payment plans are made available for patients who cannot pay in full at the time of service. In addition to specifically identifiable charges discounted or forgiven entirely, FCMC provides numerous services in the community at reduced or no cost to address unmet healthcare needs. There are three K-12 school districts in the county, all of which are visited several times each school year to conduct health screenings, child safety training, and health and hygiene educational programs, etc. The home health agency of FCMC offers a regular schedule of medical screenings to adults and senior citizens within the community such as blood pressure checks and glucose and cholesterol screenings in conjunction with the laboratory services department.FCMC holds numerous community health fairs, both alone and in conjunction with other providers in the area. The arrival of autumn signals the annual "Healthy Sportsman Fair" which is attended by hundreds for a wide variety of health screenings offered at nominal or no cost. October (to coincide with Breast Cancer Awareness Month) brings a week-long healthy woman event which focuses on the specific needs of females. FCMC also provides various screenings at an annual health fair sponsored by the local FQHC to meet the needs of citizens of all ages and economic means.Fulton County Medical Center purposefully provides services at a loss as part of its mission to meet the medical needs of the community. These services include diabetes and nutritional educational education, pulmonary and cardiac rehabilitation services, which are provided at a loss since many patients have exhausted any available insurance benefits, and tobacco cessation and prevention services, which had traditionally been provided by a state-funded grant. These services are now provided on a fee-for-service basis, and FCMC has continued to provide extensive services even though the revenues received no longer cover the full cost of providing them. Fulton County Medical Center also hosts a specialty clinic, where a variety of physician and mid-level specialists see patients on a rotating basis. The costs of operating and staffing this clinic are not met by revenues. Local residents, particularly the elderly and those with chronic medical conditions, are grateful for the opportunity to see qualified specialists without traveling over the mountainous area for distances of 30-50 miles or more for these services.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The assets of the Fulton County Medical Center Auxiliary are held by the Fulton County Medical Center.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.ReturnReference: Description of Uncertain Tax Positions Under FIN 48:
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The Medical Center qualifies as a tax-exempt organization described in Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code. Accordingly, the Medical Center is not subject to federal income taxes under Section 501(c)(3) of the Code. The Medical Center is classified as a publicly supported charitable organization under Section 501(c)(3) of the Code, and contributions to the Medical Center qualify as a charitable tax deduction by the contributor. The Medical Center undergoes an annual analysis of its various tax positions, assessing the likelihood of those positions being upheld upon examination with relevant tax authorities, as defined by accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America. No liabilities have been recorded as a result of this analysis. Under normal circumstances, the Medical Center is no longer subject to Federal and state tax examinations by tax authorities for taxable years before 2007.

Form990ScheduleHPartVI.IncomeBasedCriteria: Part I, Line 3c: Patients with no health insurance, private or employer-sponsored insurance, or governmental program, are automatically eligible for a Tier I Financial Assistance Discount in the following amounts:* Inpatient services 30%* Outpatient services 40%* Home Health services 20%* Swing bed services 30%
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.CostingMethodUsed: Part I, Line 7: Charity care expense was converted to cost on line 7a using the cost-to-charge ratio derived from Worksheet 2. Unreimbursed Medicaid on line 7b was calculated using the cost-to-charge ratio derived from Worksheet 2. Community health improvement services, line 7e, and cash and in-kind contributions to community groups, line 7i, are reported from the client's general ledger. The cost for subsidized health services on line 7g was determined using the Medicare cost report.
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.SubsidizedHealthServicesExpln: Part I, Line 7g: The organization did not include any costs attributable to a physician clinic as subsidized health services.
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.PercentOfTotalExpenseExpln: Part I, Line 7f: The amount of bad debt expense removed from total expenses to detemine the percentage was $1,826,666.
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.BadDebtFootnote: Part III, Line 4: The organization's bad debt expense was converted to cost using the cost to charge ratio derived from Worksheet 2.Prior to any account being classified as bad debt, all payments are applied including contractual allowances and discounts, and every effort is made with the patient in an attempt to collect the outstanding balance. Accounts placed with a collection that are 180 days old from discharge date and no payment has been received within 120 days are written off to bad debt. If a payment is received on an amount previously written off to bad debt, the amount would reduce bad debt expense. Fulton County Medical Center does not refuse service to patients that generate bad debt.The estimated amount of the organization's bad debt expense attributable to patients eligible under the organization's charity care policy is calculated based on an estimate of charity care accounts compared to total bad debt accounts.Footnote to financial statements:The carrying amount of patient and resident receivables is reduced by a valuation allowance that reflects management's estimate of amounts that will not be collected from patients, residents, and third-party payors. Management reviews patient receivables by payor class and applies percentages to determine estimated amounts that will not be collected from third parties under contractual agreements and amounts that will not be collected from patients and residents due to bad debts. Management considers historical write off and recovery information in determining the estimated bad debt provision.
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.ShortfallAsCommunityBenefit: Part III, Line 8: The entire shortfall is considered a community benefit. Fulton County Medical Center provides services to patients under the Medicare program knowing they will not recover all the costs associated with providing these services. Providing these services is essential for the health of these patients and increases their access to healthcare services.Total revenue received from Medicare was reported from the revenue usage report. Medicare allowable costs were reported from the Medicare cost report.
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.DebtCollectionPolicy: Part III, Line 9b: Patients applying for charity care or financial assistance, or patients who are known to qualify for free or discounted care, will be processed as such before collection efforts start. Once a determination is made on eligibility, any personal portion due is subject to the same collection policy as other accounts.If the patient does not have third party insurance coverage, they will be informed of the Free Care Program. Eligibility will be determined using the Department of Health and Human Services Income Poverty Guidelines Category B with no sliding scale. Patients/Guarantors who have not met arrangements to pay off their accounts within the allotted time will be forwarded to the Hospitals Collection Agency. All accounts will be reviewed by the Financial Advocate prior to agency referral.
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.NumberOfFacilityTypeExpln: Part V: The organization also has the following type of facility other than those required to be licensed as healthcare facilities in the state of Pennsylvania:1 specialty clinic
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.NeedsAssessment: Part VI, Line 2: Health care needs for Fulton County Medical Center have been assessed using both internal and external means. Internally recommendations are received from staff and physicians (both hospital based and visiting) of potential services patients may be requesting. In addition, at the annual board retreat, during the development of the strategic plan, current and future services are discussed that will benefit the community. Externally, a study was prepared in January 2010 by the following organizations; National Center for Rural Health Works at Oklahoma Cooperative Extension Service, Oklahoma State University and Oklahoma Center for Rural Health at Oklahoma Office of Rural Health, OSU Health Sciences Center College of Osteopathic Medicine, Oklahoma State University and National Association of Counties Project which was funded by the federal Office of Rural Health. The work completed by these groups provided an analysis of the demand for primary care practitioners and specialty physicians for Fulton County Medical Center. This document will be used when considering the needs of our community.
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.PatientEducationAssistance: Part VI, Line 3: The Fulton County Medical Center posts information about the financial assistance program at the admission/ER areas, business office and financial advocate's office. This information is included in the inpatient and outpatient surgery patient packets. The financial advocate discusses with the patient the availability of various government benefits, such as Medicaid, and assists the patient with qualification for such programs, where applicable.
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.CommunityInformation: Part VI, Line 4: The Fulton County Medical Center is in a rural area with an estimated population in 2009 of 14,852 people. The Fulton County Medical Center is the only medical facility in the county. The closest hospital is 19.0 miles away and patients would have to travel over mountainous, rural terrain. The payor mix for Medicaid and Self Pay are 18% and 7% respectively.
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.CommunityBuildingActivities: Part VI, Line 5: Included in the community health improvement advocacy are net expenses of $3,580 for the smoking cessation program.
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.OtherInformation: Part VI, Line 6: Fulton County Medical Center's (FCMC) board is comprised of citizens from the communities and service areas that benefit from FCMC's services. FCMC is the only hospital and nursing home in this rural service area. Patients who come to the ER are not denied treatment based on the ability to pay. FCMC offers financial assistance and charity care for those patients who have a limited or no means to pay their medical bill. In addition to the hospital, FCMC offers a skilled nursing home and a specialty services clinic where visiting specialists are able to see patients so that the patients do not need to leave the community to receive medical care. To meet the needs of our community, the hospital extends privileges to medical staff that are licensed. Staff from the medical center visits the schools in the area to remind children of healthy habits they should practice. As well as several community health fairs are held such as women's health fair and a healthy hunter's health fair. Support groups such as an Alzheimer's support group are also offered to the community. FCMC participates in educating healthcare professionals with nursing students from a local college completing a portion of their education at FCMC. Surplus funds are used for facility and equipment upgrades to further the exempt purpose of the organization.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 4
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The number of Board of Directors was changed from 14 to 13. Board members and Community members cannot be employees of Fulton County Medical Center unless otherwise specified according to bylaws.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The return is reviewed by the CFO and Controller. Fulton County Medical Center's Finance Committee receives a copy of the 990 at the February meeting, following the filing of the tax return.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Any possible conflict of interest on the part of a Director must be disclosed to the Board. A conflict of interest form is completed annually by all officers, directors, and key employees. The forms are reviewed by the CEO. When any interest becomes a matter of Board action, the Director is not to vote or use personal influence on the matter, and is not counted in the quorum for a meeting at which Board action is to be taken on the interest. The Director may, however, briefly state a position on the matter and answer pertinent questions of Board members. The minutes of all actions taken on such matters clearly reflect that these requirements have been met. It is the obligation of each Board member to act in the best interest of the Medical Center. All Board information is confidential, and is not to be used or discussed other than for appropriate Medical Center business. Failure of a Director to maintain the confidentiality of Board information is be grounds for removal.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Board of Directors serves as a compensation committee and reviews and adjusts the compensation of the CEO and CFO based on annual evaluations and comparability data. The Human Resources Department conducts a survey to gather comparability data and gives this information to the Board of Directors. The process is documented and was last completed in FY 2010.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The organization makes it governing documents, conflict of interest policy, and financial statements available upon request or through an annual meeting which is open to the general public.
The following individuals devoted time providing services to Fulton County Medical Center Foundation, a related organization. Jason Hawkins 2 hours per week Deborah Shughart 2 hours per week

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Schedule R, Part V, line 2:
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The method used to determine the amounts on lines 2(1) and 2(2) was cash transfers noted in the audited financial statements.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, Line 1a:
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Executive Committee consists of Officers of the board and each Committee Chairperson. The President/CEO is an ex-officio, non-voting member of the Executive Committee. The Chairperson of the board acts as the Chairperson of the Executive Committee. From time to time the Executive Committee may need to meet on an emergency basis to address time sensitive issues. In such cases, the Executive Committee may exercise all of the powers of the Board of Directors to transact the regular business of the Medical Center to the extent permitted by law, provided any action taken does not conflict with the policies and express wishes of the Board of Directors, and it reports its actions at the next board meeting. The Executive Committee also ensures that the Board of Directors completes an annual self-evaluation of the boards performance. The Committee arranges for a regular program on continuing education for all members of the board, and assures that a proper orientation program is required for all new board members.

Form990ScheduleRPartII.PrimaryActivities: Provide support to Fulton County Medical Center
